title: Cramer's Rule, Volume, and Linear Transformations

sections.title: Introduction (Wide Shot)
sections.content: Hey, I’m Jihad Al Sayed. In this tutorial, we're covering Cramer's Rule, its connection to determinants, and how volume and linear transformations all tie together in a beautiful way.

sections.title: What is Cramer's Rule?
sections.content: Cramer's Rule lets you solve a system Ax = b using determinants, but it only works when A is invertible.

sections.title: The Formula
sections.math: x_i = \frac{\det(A_i)}{\det(A)},\quad \text{where } A_i \text{ is A with column } i \text{ replaced by } b

sections.title: Volume Scaling by Determinants
sections.content: The absolute value of the determinant of A tells you how much the transformation T(x) = Ax scales volume in space.

sections.title: Geometric Insight
sections.content: If \det(A) = 2, every unit cube becomes a volume-2 box. If \det(A) = 0, volume collapses — the transformation flattens space.

sections.title: Linear Transformations Revisited
sections.math: T(\vec{x}) = A\vec{x},\quad \det(A) \text{ shows how T scales space}

sections.title: Recap
sections.content: We explored Cramer’s Rule for solving systems, understood the volume-scaling role of determinants, and tied it all back to how linear transformations behave. Determinants aren’t just numbers — they reshape space.
